top_categories.workout_context: Chequamegon MTB's Chequamegon National Forest roads (60%), Singletrack (40%) forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 40 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Chequamegon MTB's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before September.
When someone attacks on chequamegon National Forest—MTB singletrack +, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Chequamegon MTB, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on chequamegon National Forest—MTB singletrack +. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Smooth pedaling at 40 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.
100ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At Chequamegon MTB, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
40 miles on chequamegon National Forest—MTB singletrack + burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Varied gradients on chequamegon National Forest—MTB singletrack + demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Chequamegon MTB. Train it until it feels boring.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 4,000ft of climbing on chequamegon National Forest—MTB singletrack + does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Chequamegon MTB’s 40 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Chequamegon MTB demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride chequamegon national forest—mtb singletrack + forest roads at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: chequamegon national forest roads (60%), singletrack (40%), technical mtb terrain. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 40 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and VO2max to prepare you for 40 miles of chequamegon national forest—mtb singletrack + forest roads in Cable, Wisconsin (Chequamegon National Forest).
